I'm almost done with the Perl code of my NEAT version.  I did some things 
differently than tradition, and I'd like some feedback  on whether there are 
any obvious blunders to it...

First, each network topology is a distinct species, period.

Second, I only form a maximum of one new topology per generation, period.  
And then, only if there is room in the population for one.

"room" is determined by how many are left after offspring allocation.  This 
is made possible by the fact that I have a very precise set of searches that 
are done within any given topology:

1. best member passes on unchanged (elites)
2. best member has its weights tweaked
3. best member is crossed with 2nd best, and weights are averaged
4. best member is crossed with 2nd best, and weights are randomly selected 
from one parent or the other
5. 2nd best passes on unchanged (2nd elite)
6. 2nd best has its weights tweaked
7. 1st best is crossed with a random other, weights averaged
8. 2nd best is crossed with a random other, weights averaged
9. 1st best is crossed with a random other, weights chosen randomly from 
parents
10. 2nd best crossed with random other, randomly
11. all new weights are chosen at random

If, due to fitness sharing, only 5 offspring are allowed, it only gets the 
first 5.  If it should get 12, it still only gets 11, but there is room in 
the population for searching more topology, and so a topological mutation is 
allowed.  One, for the whole population, chosen at random from the elites in 
the population.

There is also a stagnation penalty.  When calculating fitness sharing, each 
species/topology is penalized 1% for every generation since the last time it 
improved.  If it does improve, that penalty is not immediately removed, but 
cut in half.  That way, investment rises rapidly, but not all the way.

The idea is that since a species is a fixed topology, it can't get un-stuck 
by adding structure.  Adding structure creates new species.  So, as the 
topology stagnates, the likelihood of making a breakthrough in that 
particular structure diminishes.  Thus, our computational investment in it 
diminishes.  As our investment in that species decreases, that makes 
available more resources for more profitable avenues of searching.  But 
since there is a limited number of slots per topology, eventually we will 
have more available slots than we can use.  That's when structure gets 
added.  When that happens, there is a 75% chance that the change will be the 
addition of a new connection.  20% chance of splitting an existing 
connection.  And %5 chance of deleting an existing connection.

The idea is to thoroughly focus on weight adjustment to the exclusion of 
topological variation so long as it is making headway.  Then to focus on 
connectivity before layers.  And addition before deletion.

Like I said, any obvious problems with this idea?  Any suggestions of 
specific data that should be gathered to make sure the design works, besides 
ability so solve a particular problem?

Thanks!

-- John
